metadata.title: Utilization of waste marble powder in cement-based materials by incorporating nano silica

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Utilization of waste marble powder in cement-based materials by incorporating nano silica
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.03.248 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: thbwhut@whut.edu.cn (H. Tan).
Baoguo Ma a, Jie Wang a, Hongbo Tan a,⇑, Xiangguo Li a, Lixiong Cai b, Yang Zhou a, Zhugen Chu a a State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, PR China b School of Civil Engineering and Mechanics, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, PR China
h i g h l i g h t s
Waste marble powder and nano silica were used as partial replacement of cement. Replacement of cement by waste marble powder decreased the strength of mortar. NS improved the mechanical property mortar containing waste marble powder.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 1 January 2019 Received in revised form 18 March 2019 Accepted 19 March 2019
Keywords: Nano silica Waste marble powder Mechanical property Hydration process Microstructure
a b s t r a c t
In order to promote the utilization of waste marble powder (WMP) in cement-based materials, an attempt to improve the mechanical properties of cement-WMP system by incorporating nano silica (NS) was made in this study. 16 mortar mixes incorporating NS (0%, 1%, 2% and 3%) and WMP (0%, 10%, 20% and 30%) as partial replacement of Portland cement were designed. Mechanical properties, standard water requirement, setting time and the fluidity were investigated, and the hydration and microstructure characteristics were also analyzed with hydration heat, X-ray diffraction (XRD), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Results demonstrated that replacement of cement by WMP obviously reduced the compressive strength, despite that calcite in WMP partly reacted with aluminum phase to produce the carbonate AFm phase instead of monosulphate. Furthermore, NS showed positive effect on strength development of cement-WMP system, and the reason was due to the nucleation effect, filler effect and its ultra-high pozzolanic reactivity. NS could partially offset the adverse effect on the compressive strength of mortar caused by WMP, and 10% WMP and 3% NS showed an optimum proportion. Such findings were expected to expedite the use of WMP in cement-based materials.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Marble, known as a metamorphic rock transformed from pure limestone, are increasingly used in building materials industry in China. In the process of marble processing, a large amount of waste powder, occupied approximately 30% of raw marble, was produced after being cut or polished as a by-product; waste marble powder (WMP) has resulted in serious environment pollution and nature resource waste. Its disposal is plaguing many other countries [1– 3], such as Italy, Brazil, Spain, Sweden, Belgium, France, Egypt and Turkey, etc., and finding an effective way to utilize this powder waste is of great importance for further development of marble industry.
On the other hand, in cement and concrete industry, the demand of supplementary materials (SM) is increasing in recent years; considering the saving of nature resource consumption [4– 6], industrial solid waste has been accepted as a main alternative for SM [7–10]. Marble are composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) and dolomite (Mg(CaCO3)2), with a small amount of other kinds of minerals, such as silica, feldspar and mica [11,12]; marble powder was reported to be utilized as supplementary materials to partly replace cement, in order to obtain great economic and environmental benefits [13–17]. However, compressive strength and workability should be considered carefully. Soliman [18] reported that more than 5% content of marble powder substantially reduced the compressive strength of concrete, and the reason was ascribed to the reduction of cement mineral phase (C2S and C3S) in system. Ergün [19] found that the mechanical properties would be improved when replacement ratio of marble powder less than
7.5%, while the compressive strength began to decrease when the replacement ratio up to 15%. Vardhan [17] reported that 10% replacement kept the compressive strength of mortar almost the same with the reference, but the workability was obviously improved. Shirule [20] also confirmed the obvious improvement in the workability of fresh mixture with addition of WMP, but the compressive strength and tensile strength of concrete were still increased when WMP was added up to 10%. Belaidi [21] investigated the effect of WMP on the properties of self-compacting concrete, and the results also confirmed the positive effect of WMP on rheology of fresh concrete. Based on discussion above, it was found that addition of WMP obviously improved the rheology of the cement-based materials, but the compressive strength of cement-WMP system should be carefully noticed if the dosage surpassed the threshold.
In order to promote the use of WMP in cement-based materials, the strength of cement-WMP system should be improved. As reported in the literatures, chemical and physical activation were generally employed to activate the reactivity of the SM. Because of almost none pozzolanic reaction activity of WMP, chemical activation for cement should be firstly considered. It was proved that sodium sulfate [22], alkanolamine [23–25], and silica fume (SF) could significantly promote the strength of cement paste as a reuslt of accelerate the hydration of cement minerals. Taking sodium sulfate for example, formation of ettringite could be accelerated to contribute the early strength, but with negative effect on later strength. Alkanolamine, such as triisopropanolamine and triethanolamine, could hasten the dissolution of silicate and aluminate to accelerate the hydration; and especially for cement-fly ash system, the dissolution of fly ash could be significantly promoted, thereby accelerating the hydration of system to contribute the strength obviously [26]. Similar results were also observed in cement-MWP system added SF. Khodabakhshian [27] found that 10% SF made the strength of cement with 5–20% MWP replacement ratio even higher than the cement system, and that for 2.5–5% SF could also obtain acceptable performance in mechanical strength and durability at older ages. They also reported that the combine use of MWP and SF improved the mechanical properties and it would have environmental benefits and expedite the utilization of marble industry waste powder [28]. These researches can help us understand the basic performance of cement-WMP system.
In the literatures, nano-silica (NS), with much finer particles than SF, was reported to show much higher reactivity than SF; addition of NS could noticeably promote the cement hydration, refine the pore structure, and enhance the strength, because of its high reaction activity [29–33]. In this study, in order to improve the strength by inducing the hydration of cement minerals, an attempt to add NS was made. Cement-WMP-NS system was designed, and the workability, mechanical properties, hydration heat, and hydration products were carefully investigated in terms of water requirement, setting time, compressive strength, calorimeter, XRD, SEM, and NMR. The findings were expected to promote the utilization of WMP in cement-based materials.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. Materials
Locally available type I Portland cement (PC, P.I 52.5, produced by Huaxin cement Co., Ltd.) was used in this research. Waste marble powder (WMP) was procured from Zhengzhou, Henan province, China. Nano silica (NS) with an average particle size of 14 nm was purchased from Shanghai Huiping Chemical Co., Ltd.
The chemical composition of cement, WMP and NS are listed in Table 1. Fig. 1 shows the particle size distribution of cement and WMP. The d50 of cement and WMP particles are 12.2 lm and 8.7 lm, respectively. The mineralogical and microstructural properties of cement and WMP were characterized by XRD and SEM, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of cement and WMP. The main
mineral components of WMP are calcite (CaCO3) and dolomite (Mg(CaCO3)2). The microscopic morphology of WMP and NS were characterized with SEM and TEM, respectively, as shown in Figs. 3 and 4.
Standard sand (SS) in accordance with Chinese national standards [34] was used as aggregate for mortar. Running water was used for the preparation and curing.
2.2. Sample preparation
All paste and mortar samples kept a water-to-binder ratio (w/b, binder = cement + WMP + NS) of 1/2 and a binder-to-sand ratio (b/s) of 1/3 in this study, with or without WMP and NS addition.
The mix proportions were designed as shown in Table 2. These mixtures were designed to reflect the impact of WMP and NS on the properties of hydration and hardening process of cement-based materials. Cement and WMP were firstly preblended for 5 min to ensure the uniformity of powder material. NS was dispersed by ultrasonication in water for 5 min before being mixed with other materials to attain a homogeneous solution.
Cement mortar samples for mechanical testing were prepared and cured according to GB/T 17671-1999 [35] for strength testing. Cement paste samples for microscopic testing (XRD, SEM and 29Si NMR) were cast in molds with a dimension of 40 mm 40 mm 40 mm. After 3, 7 and 28 days curing, the hydration process of cement paste was terminated by immersing the crushed samples in absolute ethyl alcohol for 3 days. The samples were oven dried at 60 C for 12 h, and then a portion of the samples were ground in an agate mortar to pass through a 200-mesh size sieve for XRD and NMR testing; small pieces of the samples were used for SEM testing.
2.3. Testing method
2.3.1. Mechanical properties The fluidity of mortar was measured according to GB/T 2419-2005 [36]. The setting time test was conducted according to GB/T 1346-2011 [37]. The compressive strength of mortar was carried out in accordance with GB/T 17671-1999 [35].
2.3.2. Hydration heat evolution For hydration heat test, Portland cement blended with varying content of WMP were prepared and mixed for 5 min. Meantime, different dosages of NS was dispersed by ultrasonication in water to form a homogeneous suspension. The water/binder ratio was 1.0. The heat evolution was conducted over a period of 72 h, and the data was recorded automatically. The hydration heat evolution of
paste was measured by an isothermal conduction calorimeter (produced by TA America) to assess the effect of NS andWMP on the hydration heat of cement pastes at 20 C.
2.3.3. XRD analysis The mineral composition of samples was investigated by a X-ray diffractometry (Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) with a Cu ka X-ray source. The accelerating voltage, accelerating current, step size, dwelling time of the test during data collection was 40 kV, 40 mA, 0.02 , and 1 s, respectively.
2.3.4. 29Si MAS-NMR analysis Solid-state NMR was characterized by a Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHz spectrometer. The hydration degree of cement (apc) and the average chain length (ACL) of C-S-H gel can be calculated as the following formulas (Eqs. (1) and (2)) [38,39]:
aPC %ð Þ ¼ 1 I Q0
I Q0 þ I Q1 þ I Q2
2 4
3 5 100% ð1Þ
ACL ¼ 2I Q1 þ 2I Q2
I Q1 ð2Þ
where I(Q0), I(Q1) and I(Q2) represent the integrated intensities of signals Q0, Q1 and Q2, respectively.
2.3.5. Microstructure characterization Microstructure was characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) at a accelerating voltage of 15 kV.
2.3.6. Mercury intrusion porosimetry The pore structure and pore size distribution of different pastes were characterized by mercury intrusion porosimetry (Auto Pore IV 9510, America). The pressure of test was less than 420 MPa and the contact angle was 140 .

sections.heading: 3.1. Standard water requirement and workability
sections.text:
Workability was accepted as one of the basic properties of cement-based materials. In this study, the workability of cement mortar was evaluated by the fluidity value. The effect of NS and WMP on the fluidity values of cement mortar are shown in Fig. 5. For the WMP-cement mixture, the fluidity increased with the increasing WMP replacement ratio. For example, 10%, 20% and 30% of WMP increased the fluidity from 196 mm in reference to 202 mm, 208 mm, and 215 mm, respectively. In the presence of NS, the phenomenon that WMP increased fluidity was also
found. Furthermore, it was worth noting that NS exhibited the negative effect on the workability of the fresh mixture. As seen in the figure, in cement-NS system, 3.0% NS reduced the fluidity from 196 mm in reference to 155 mm. In cement-WMP-NS system, the same tendency was also observed. Moreover, it was interesting that positive effect of WMP on fluidity might offset the negative effect caused by NS. For instance, in cement-30% WMP-1.0% NS system, the fluidity value was 197 mm, which was slightly higher than that of the cement.
Water requirement was one of the parameters influencing the fluidity of paste [40]. Fig. 6 shows the water requirement of each mixture. As seen in Fig. 6, in cement-WMP system, the standard water requirement was reduced from 24% in reference to 22.5% in 30% WMP system; in the cement-WMP-3% NS, the standard water requirement was reduced from 25.5% in reference to 24.5% in 30% WMP system; these results indicated that water requirement of WMP was lower than that of cement. This result agreed with the previous research achieved by Aliabdo [41]. Furthermore, in cement paste, 3% NS increased the standard water requirement from 24% in reference to 25.3%; in cement-10% WMP system, the increase was from 23.5% in reference to 24.9%, and that in cement-20% WMP system and cement-30% WMP system was from 23% to 24.9% and from 22.5% to 24.5%. These results indicated that NS greatly increased the water requirement.
Based on discussion of water requirement and workability, it was concluded that WMP decreased the water requirement and increased the fluidity, while the opposite was true for NS. The reason for decrease was that cement composed of cement minerals could react with water as hydration, resulting in the higher water requirement than that of WMP. The other reason was that the smaller WMP particles, with relatively slippery surface, filled in the voids among cement particles and released the filling water, thus providing more lubricating water and reducing the friction between the cement particles, which consequently improved the workability of mortar. Furthermore, the increased water requirement by NS was not only because the ultra-high special surface area of NS required more water to lubrication [42,43], but also due to the fact that NS with high reaction activity reacted immediately with Ca(OH)2 and formed C-S-H gel with high water consumption [44]. NS particles were easily aggregated together and also led to a decrease in the fluidity of cement mortar, which
greatly reduced the amount of lubricating water available in the intergranular space. Even though the positive effect of WMP on fluidity might offset the negative effect of NS, the water requirement should be considered in the use of cement-WMP-NS system.

sections.heading: 3.2. Setting time
sections.text: As shown in Fig. 7, the addition of WMP delayed the setting process of the pastes. For instance, when 10% WMP was incorporated, the initial and final setting was delayed by 20 min and 22 min, respectively. This may be due to the reduction of cement clinker, which certainly led to the reduction in the amount of hydration products. Nevertheless, no significant changes were observed in setting time of pastes with the continued increase inWMP content. Furthermore, it was also seen that whether for plain cement or WMP-cement pastes, the addition of NS caused a significant decrease in the initial and final setting time. This phenomenon could be accounted for the acceleration effect of NS on cement hydration [45]. NS particles in cementitious materials acted as nucleation sites, thus promoting the formation of hydration products [46–48]. In this case, the setting time of cement paste was also remarkably shortened.

sections.heading: 3.3. Compressive strength
sections.text:
The effect of NS and WMP on the compressive strength of cement mortar at 3, 7, 28 and 56 days is shown in Table 3. As seen in Table 3, the compressive strength of mortar decreased dramatically with the WMP content. For instance, the 28 days compressive strength of W10N0, W20N0 and W30N0 decreased by 10%, 20% and 27%, respectively, compared to that of cement mortar. Similar results were reported by Arel [49] and Ergün [19]. Due to the low activity of WMP, the substitution of WMP reduced the content of clinker (C3S and C2S), thus certainly leading to the decrease in compressive strength of mortar.
From Table 3, it was also found that the compressive strength of cement and cement-WMP mortar were improved by the addition of NS at early ages, and the higher NS dosage resulted in higher compressive strength. For instance, the compressive strength of W0N1, W0N2 and W0N3 was 7%, 10% and 17% higher than that of W0N0 at 3 days, respectively. Moreover, the compressive strength of mortar containing WMP also increased with the NS dosage. The compressive strength of W10N3, W20N3 and W30N3 at 3 days increased by 19%, 15% and 20% compared to WMP-cement mortar without NS addition, respectively. With the
extension of curing time, the compressive strength of mortar showed the similar tendency. The results were attributed to the special physical and chemical characteristics of NS. As reported in the literatures, NS with high reaction activity could react with calcium hydroxide which generated during the cement hydration process, resulting in forming additional C-S-H gel with contribution to mechanical strength [32,50]. Additionally, nano particles also filled the pores and reduced the porosity in cement pastes, thus improving the mechanical properties of the mortar [51]. In summary, under consideration of compressive strength, 10% WMP and 3% NS may be an optimum proportion for the cementWMP-NS ternary system.

sections.heading: 3.4. Hydration heat evolution
sections.text:
Hydration heat release is one of the basic properties of cement hydration. The accumulated heat and heat flow rate can describe the hydration process of cement. To investigate the influence of NS and WMP on the hydration of cement at early stage, the hydration heat of several mixtures was investigated.
The heat flow rate of hydration of mixtures is illustrated in Fig. 8. Two major exothermic peaks were observed in the heat flow curves. The first exothermic peak was observed at ca. 5 min, which corresponded to the hydration of C3A. A secondary peak corresponding to the hydration of C3S followed this peak, which
appeared at ca. 10 h. As shown in Fig. 8(A) and (B), the exothermic peak intensity of both the first and second peaks significantly decreased with the increasing WMP replacement ratio. Moreover, the second exothermic peak of W10N0 was noted to appear 34.6 min earlier than W0N0. However, when WMP replacement level exceeded 10%, the second exothermic peak was slightly delayed with increasing WMP content. Likewise, the accumulated heat during 72 h (Table 4) of sample containing 10% WMP was 5.9% higher than that of W0N0, indicating the accelerating effect of WMP. This might be due to the formation of carbonaluminate during the hydration process [52]. The calcite present in cementWMP system reacted with calcium aluminate to form hemicarbonate, and then the hemicarbonate would gradually convert into monocarboaluminate over time [53]. However, the total released heat had a dramatic decrease along with the further increase in WMP content. In comparison with W0N0, the accumulated heat of W20N0 and W30N0 decreased by 12.18% and 28.87%, respectively. This was primarily due to dilution effect of WMP, which reduced the amount of cement minerals in system, resulting in a reduction of total heat release.
As seen in Fig. 8(C), higher first exothermic peaks were also detected, and the higher the NS dosage was added, the more noticeable the enhancement effect was observed. The second exothermic peak of W20N1, W20N2 and W20N3 (Fig. 8(D)) appeared 46.7 min, 107.8 min and 127.4 min earlier and the peak intensity increased by 18.4%, 30.9% and 49.8% than those of W20N0, respectively. What’s more, the exothermic peak value of W20N3 was higher than W0N0, which implied faster hydration reaction rate. As shown in Table 4, the accumulated heat of the samples incorporating 20% WMP increased by 27.8%, 32.0% and 39.4% when 1%, 2% and 3% NS were incorporated, respectively. It was evident that the early hydration process of all samples was accelerated by NS. In other words, the reactive ultra-fine particles greatly promoted the hydration process of cement [54]: NS particles (with an average diameter of 14 nm in this study) provided potential heterogeneous nucleation sites for the formation of hydration products, and its ultra-high pozzolanic activity induced the hydration of cement minerals at early stage. These results also offered evidence to reveal the positive effect of NS on the enhancement of early age strength of mortars.

sections.heading: 3.5. XRD analysis
sections.text:
To further study the difference in hydration products of different mixes, W0N0, W30N0 andW30N3 samples hydrated for 7 days
and 28 days were characterized with XRD instrument, and the results were displayed in Fig. 9. Ettringite (E), monosulphate (Ms), hemicarbonate (Hc), monocarbonate (Mc), ferrite (F), portlandite (CH), dicalcium silicate (C2S), tricalcium silicate (C3S), calcite (C) and dolomite (D) were found in Fig. 9(A) and (B).
As shown in Fig. 9(A), at the age of 7 days, ettringite and monosulphate were observed in W0N0 samples, which implied the formation of ettringite and the reaction of ettringite with the remaining aluminates to form monosulphate according to Eq. (3) [55]:
2C3Aþ C6AS3H32 þ 4H ! 3C4ASH12 ð3Þ However, in W30N0 sample, the peak belonging to monosulphate disappeared, and peak of monocarbonate appeared. This result indicated that the addition of WMP hastened the formation of monocarbonate and hindered the formation of monosulphate. In W30N3 sample, NS reduced the CH peak intensity in comparison with that in W30N0, indicating the pozzolanic reaction of NS. As
shown in Fig. 9(B), at the age of 28 days, in W0N0 sample, ettringite and monosulphate were also observed. In W30N0 and W30N3 samples, monocarbonate appeared instead of monosulphate, agreeing with the results at 7 days age, also indicating that the formation of monosulphate was hindered and that for monocarbonate was hastened in the presence of WMP. By constrast, in W30N0 sample, peak intensity of ettringite was reduced but that for monocarbonate was increased obviously from 7 days to 28 days. In W30N3 sample, the same result was also found. These results illustrated that ettringite in cement-WMP-NS system would transform to monocarbonate over time. It was noticed that no monosulphate phase was detected in whole hydration process in the samples containing WMP. In the previous studies, researchers found that the presence of calcite (the main component of marble) increased the CO2/SO3 ratio and prevented the conversion of ettringite to monosulphate after the sulphate depletion, which was the so called ettringite stabilization effect [56]. The dissolved carbonate ions reacted with the aluminum phase in cement to form the carbonate AFm phases (hemicarbonate and monocarbonate) according to Eqs. (4) and (5) [57,58]. The formation of carbonate AFm phases, to an extent, reduced the porosity and pore size of cement-based materials, resulting in an increase of the compressive strength [57,59,60].
Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 9, at the age of 7 days, hemicarbonate diffraction peaks was also observed in the samples containing WMP, but the peak intensity seemed not obvious. The possible reason is due to the high content of carbonate in WMP and the dedolomitization reaction of dolomite. As reported in the literatures [61,62], dolomite reacted with portlandite and formed
calcite and brucite in alkaline environment of cement paste according to Eq. (6). The dedolomitization reaction slowly increased the CO2/Al2O3 ratio of cement paste and stabilized the monocarbonate phase, which certainly lowered the amount of hemicarbonate.
C3Aþ CC þ 11H ! C4ACH11 ð4Þ
C3Aþ 0:5CC þ 0:5CH þ 11:5H ! C4AC0:5H12 ð5Þ
CMC2 þ CH ! 2CC þMH ð6Þ Additionally, it was clearly shown in Fig. 9 that the intensity of CH diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern of the samples was reduced by incorporating NS. The decrease of CH diffraction peak intensity was probably due to the high pozzolanic reactivity of NS, which consumed large amounts of CH. The additional C-S-H generated during this process was conducive to the development of mechanical properties of cement-based materials.

sections.heading: 3.6. 29Si NMR analysis
sections.text:
To further illustrate the effect of NS and WMP on the hydration of cement paste, 29Si NMR was used to characterize the hydrated paste samples. The results are presented in Fig. 10.
The peak of Q0 located at around 70 ppm in the spectra represented the unhydrated calcium silicate in cement[63]. The peaks located at around 79 ppm and 84 ppm corresponding to the Q1 and Q2 in C-S-H gels [64], respectively. In order to differentiate the peaks in 29Si NMR spectra obtained from the instrument, computer deconvolution was made by Gaussian line shapes for quan-
tification. The relative intensity of Qn, the hydration degree of cement (apc) and the average chain length (ACL) of C-S-H gel are presented in Table 5.
It was observed from the above results that the cement hydration degree was 70.45% and 30% WMP replacement increased it to 77.22%; further addition of NS increased it to 78.23%. It indicated
Table 5 Quantitative results from the deconvolution of 29Si NMR spectra.
Sample Mix proportion Relative intensity of Qn/% apc/% ACL
Q0 Q1 Q2
W0N0 cement 29.54 60.8 9.66 70.45 2.32 W30N0 cement +30%WMP 22.78 66.49 10.73 77.22 2.32 W30N3 cement +30%WMP +3%NS 21.76 60.27 17.96 78.23 2.59
that WMP in this system hastened the hydration of cement [65], and the reason was attributed to the dilution effect of WMP caused by the replacement of cement. The promoted hydration of cement
by NS was mainly because of the pozzolanic reaction of NS to induce the cement hydration.
Furthermore, the ACL value of the samples did not show any difference between W0N0 and W30N0, indicating that WMP did not take part in polycondensation of silicate. However, an increase in ACL was observed between W30N0 and W30N3, indicating that NS increased the average chain length of C-S-H; the reason was that NS participated in polycondensation of silicate by the pozzolanic reaction. In summary, the enhancement effect of NS on the hydration process of cement-WMP system was confirmed, and this could reveal the reason for the compressive strength increase and hydration heat evolution.

sections.heading: 3.7. Microstructure
sections.text:
To investigate the effect of NS and WMP on the microstructure of cement paste, the morphology of hydration products was characterized with SEM, and the SEM images of 28 days samples are shown in Fig. 11. As shown in Fig. 11(A), lots of loose fibrous-like C-S-H gel was observed in W0N0 and some massive hexagonal platy calcium hydroxide (CH) crystal embed into the C-S-H gel was also being found. It exhibited a loose microstructure with large amounts of voids. In the W30N0 sample (Fig. 11(B)), the hydration products grew along the surface of the WMP particles; the C-S-H gel diffused around in a cluster shape. Replacement of cement by WMP led to a reduction in the amount of effective cementitious material, which resulted in the decrease of hydration products. According to Fig. 11(C), a much denser microstructure with plenty of sponge-like C-S-H gel filling into the voids was detected compared to Fig. 11(B), due to the positive effect of NS. Based on the above results, it could be concluded that the addition of NS remarkably improved the microstructure of cement and cementWMP samples, which could be used to explain the aforementioned higher compressive strength of both cement-NS and cementWMP-NS system.
Table 6 Pore size distribution of different pastes at 28 days.

sections.heading: 3.8. Pore structure
sections.text:
The pore size distribution of different pastes at 28 days is shown in Fig. 12 and Table 6. Pore structure is closely related to the properties of cement-based materials, especially the compressive strength [66,67]. The pores of cementitious materials can be divided into the following categories according to the pore size: harmless pore, less-harmful pore, harmful pore and moreharmful pore [68]. As seen from Table 6, with 30% WMP addition, the porosity of W30N0 decreased from 0.2083 mL/g to 0.1946 mL/
g, and the harmful and more-harmful pores gradually shift to lessharmful pores. What’s more, the most probable pore-size decreased from 39.9 nm to 35.3 nm (Fig. 12), which implied the refinement of pore structure. This was mainly because of the filling effect of WMP. For W30N3 paste, 3% NS further reduced the porosity to 0.1792 mL/g, the most probable pore-size decreased to 29.6 nm. This result further confirmed the refined pore structure by NS, in agreement with the results shown in the SEM image. The refinement effect of NS on cement-WMP system was inferred as one of the reasons for the increment of compressive strength.
To further illustrate the pore refinement mechanism of cementWMP-NS system, the schematic diagram of the ternary system was proposed (Fig. 13). When WMP was added as partial replacement of cement, smaller particles filled in the voids among cement particles, leading to the reduction of porosity of cement-based materials. Furthermore, WMP particles reacted with the remaining aluminum phase to produce the carbonate AFm phase; as shown in Fig. 14, the sheet-shaped AFm, namely hemicarbonate (Hc), monocarbonate (Mc) was observed clearly. In the literature, solid phase volume was increased during the chemical reaction, as shown in Eqs. (7) and (8) [57]. During the chemical reactions, the overall solid phase volume increased significantly due to the larger molar volume of hydration products, such as Hc and Mc. Meanwhile, these hydrates were formed on surface of WMP particles as a cementitious layer to strengthen the interfaces, which was very different from the other filling particles (shown in Fig. 13). Formation of Hc and Mc is inferred as one of the factors contribute to compressive strength.
C3Aþ CC þ 11H ! C4ACH11 89 cm3=molþ 37 cm3=mol ! 262 cm3=mol;DV ¼ 108% ð7Þ
C3Aþ 0:5CC þ 0:5CH þ 11:5H ! C4AC0:5H12 89 cm3=mol þ 0:5 37 cm3=molþ 0:5 33 cm3=mol
! 285 cm3=mol;DV ¼ 130% ð8Þ Additionally, when NS was incorporated, NS particles filled in the nano-sized pores once mixed with other materials [69,70]. The uniformly dispersed NS particles provided crystallization nucleation sites for hydration products and accelerated the hydration process. As shown in Fig. 13, the added NS particles in the interspace among cement particles act as nucleation seed, inducing the ions to gather around nano particles where the hydrates would be produced. On the other hand, owing to its ultra-high pozzolanic reactivity, most of the NS reacted with calcium hydroxide and formed additional C-S-H. This can exert extremely excellent filling effect in the interspace among cement particles to refine the pore structure, with contribution to strength [71–74].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Based on the analysis above, conclusions were drawn from the present work as follows:
(1) WMP improved the fluidity and extended the setting time of pastes but greatly reduced the compressive strength with the replacement ratio more than 10%, despite the fact that calcite in WMP partly reacted with aluminum phase to produce the carbonate AFm phase. The reduced strength could be attributed to reduction of C2S and C3S. (2) NS reduced the fluidity and setting time of cement-WMP system because of its ultra-high specific surface area. However, NS significantly increased the compressive strength of cement-WMP system. This was due to the nucleation effect, filler effect and ultra-high pozzolanic reactivity of NS, which significantly promoted the hydration process of cement at early stage and benefit formation of a denser microstructure. (3) The findings proposed one suggestion for utilization of WMP in cement-based materials. The combine use of WMP and NS could partially offset the negative effect caused by each other and obtain acceptable hardened properties. In this
study, 10% WMP and 3% NS may be an optimum proportion for the cement-WMP-NS ternary system.
Conflict of interest
None.

sections.text: The authors gratefully acknowledge the support of the National Key Research and Development Plan (NO. 2017YFB0310003) and the State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures (Wuhan University of Technology) (NO. SYSJJ2018-17) for supporting this research.

referenceMentions.context: Marble are composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) and dolomite (Mg(CaCO3)2), with a small amount of other kinds of minerals, such as silica, feldspar and mica [11,12]; marble powder was reported to be utilized as supplementary materials to partly replace cement, in order to obtain great economic and environmental benefits [13–17].

Soliman [18] reported that more than 5% content of marble powder substantially reduced the compressive strength of concrete, and the reason was ascribed to the reduction of cement mineral phase (C2S and C3S) in system.
Ergün [19] found that the mechanical properties would be improved when replacement ratio of marble powder less than
Vardhan [17] reported that 10% replacement kept the compressive strength of mortar almost the same with the reference, but the workability was obviously improved.

Shirule [20] also confirmed the obvious improvement in the workability of fresh mixture with addition of WMP, but the compressive strength and tensile strength of concrete were still increased when WMP was added up to 10%.
Belaidi [21] investigated the effect of WMP on the properties of self-compacting concrete, and the results also confirmed the positive effect of WMP on rheology of fresh concrete.
It was proved that sodium sulfate [22], alkanolamine [23–25], and silica fume (SF) could significantly promote the strength of cement paste as a reuslt of accelerate the hydration of cement minerals.

Alkanolamine, such as triisopropanolamine and triethanolamine, could hasten the dissolution of silicate and aluminate to accelerate the hydration; and especially for cement-fly ash system, the dissolution of fly ash could be significantly promoted, thereby accelerating the hydration of system to contribute the strength obviously [26].
Khodabakhshian [27] found that 10% SF made the strength of cement with 5–20% MWP replacement ratio even higher than the cement system, and that for 2.
They also reported that the combine use of MWP and SF improved the mechanical properties and it would have environmental benefits and expedite the utilization of marble industry waste powder [28].

This result agreed with the previous research achieved by Aliabdo [41].

Furthermore, the increased water requirement by NS was not only because the ultra-high special surface area of NS required more water to lubrication [42,43], but also due to the fact that NS with high reaction activity reacted immediately with Ca(OH)2 and formed C-S-H gel with high water consumption [44].

Furthermore, the increased water requirement by NS was not only because the ultra-high special surface area of NS required more water to lubrication [42,43], but also due to the fact that NS with high reaction activity reacted immediately with Ca(OH)2 and formed C-S-H gel with high water consumption [44].

Furthermore, the increased water requirement by NS was not only because the ultra-high special surface area of NS required more water to lubrication [42,43], but also due to the fact that NS with high reaction activity reacted immediately with Ca(OH)2 and formed C-S-H gel with high water consumption [44].
This phenomenon could be accounted for the acceleration effect of NS on cement hydration [45].
Similar results were reported by Arel [49] and Ergün [19].
Similar results were reported by Arel [49] and Ergün [19].

As reported in the literatures, NS with high reaction activity could react with calcium hydroxide which generated during the cement hydration process, resulting in forming additional C-S-H gel with contribution to mechanical strength [32,50].

As reported in the literatures, NS with high reaction activity could react with calcium hydroxide which generated during the cement hydration process, resulting in forming additional C-S-H gel with contribution to mechanical strength [32,50].
Additionally, nano particles also filled the pores and reduced the porosity in cement pastes, thus improving the mechanical properties of the mortar [51].
This might be due to the formation of carbonaluminate during the hydration process [52].
The calcite present in cementWMP system reacted with calcium aluminate to form hemicarbonate, and then the hemicarbonate would gradually convert into monocarboaluminate over time [53].

In other words, the reactive ultra-fine particles greatly promoted the hydration process of cement [54]: NS particles (with an average diameter of 14 nm in this study) provided potential heterogeneous nucleation sites for the formation of hydration products, and its ultra-high pozzolanic activity induced the hydration of cement minerals at early stage.

In the previous studies, researchers found that the presence of calcite (the main component of marble) increased the CO2/SO3 ratio and prevented the conversion of ettringite to monosulphate after the sulphate depletion, which was the so called ettringite stabilization effect [56].

The pores of cementitious materials can be divided into the following categories according to the pore size: harmless pore, less-harmful pore, harmful pore and moreharmful pore [68].

metadata.abstractText: In order to promote the utilization of waste marble powder (WMP) in cement-based materials, an attempt to improve the mechanical properties of cement-WMP system by incorporating nano silica (NS) was made in this study. 16 mortar mixes incorporating NS (0%, 1%, 2% and 3%) and WMP (0%, 10%, 20% and 30%) as partial replacement of Portland cement were designed. Mechanical properties, standard water requirement, setting time and the fluidity were investigated, and the hydration and microstructure characteristics were also analyzed with hydration heat, X-ray diffraction (XRD), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Results demonstrated that replacement of cement by WMP obviously reduced the compressive strength, despite that calcite in WMP partly reacted with aluminum phase to produce the carbonate AFm phase instead of monosulphate. Furthermore, NS showed positive effect on strength development of cement-WMP system, and the reason was due to the nucleation effect, filler effect and its ultra-high pozzolanic reactivity. NS could partially offset the adverse effect on the compressive strength of mortar caused by WMP, and 10% WMP and 3% NS showed an optimum proportion. Such findings were expected to expedite the use of WMP in cement-based materials. 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
